facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 530 of 1963 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 530 of 1963.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated February 14, 1963 of Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 34 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated February 14, 1963, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in First Appeal No. 34 of 1962.

facts.text: Eight candidates including appellant Mohan Singh and first respondent Bhanwarlal filed nomination papers for election to Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from Sitamau constituency.

anchor.surface_text: Eight candidates including the appellant Mohan Singh and the first respondent Bhanwarlal filed nomination papers for election to the Madhya Pradesh Legislative Assembly from the Sitamau constituency.

facts.text: Nomination of Hussain Khan rejected by Returning Officer at initial scrutiny.

anchor.surface_text: The nomination of one Hussain Khan was rejected by the Returning Officer at the initial scrutiny

facts.text: Himmat Singh withdrew his candidature before date of polling on February 24, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: and another candidate Himmat Singh withdrew his candidature before the date of polling, which took place on February 24, 1962.

facts.text: Polling took place on February 24, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: before the date of polling, which took place on February 24, 1962.

facts.text: Mohan Singh secured largest number of votes and was declared elected.

anchor.surface_text: On the counting of the votes Mohan Singh was found to have secured the largest number of votes at the election, and he was declared elected.

facts.text: Bhanwarlal applied under s.80 read with ss.100 and 101 of Representation of the People Act 1951 to Election Commission to declare Mohan Singh's election void, disqualify him for corrupt practices, and declare Bhanwarlal elected.

anchor.surface_text: Bhanwarlal applied under s. 80 read with ss. 100 and 101 of the Representation of the People Act 43 of 1951 , to the Election Commission of India for an order declaring the election of Mohan Singh void, and Mohan Singh disqualified because of committing corrupt practices detailed in the petition and for an order declaring the applicant Bhanwarlal elected.

facts.text: Two grounds in cls. c & d of para 11 of petition: Mohan Singh published two leaflets (annexures D & E) containing false statements of fact re personal character or conduct of Bhanwarlal, which he believed false or did not believe true, calculated to prejudice Bhanwarlal's prospects.

anchor.surface_text: Among the many grounds of corrupt practices alleged in the petition, two grounds set out in cls. c & d of para 11 of the petition survive for consideration in this appeal. It was averred in these clauses that Mohan Singh the successful candidate had shortly before the polling of votes published two leaflets in Hindi containing statements of fact with regard to the personal character or conduct of the applicant Bhanwarlal which were false and which Mohan Singh believed to be false or did not believe to be true and that the statements were calculated to prejudice the prospects of Bhanwarlal at the election.

facts.text: Petition referred for trial by Election Commission to Election Tribunal Ratlam under s.86 RPA.

anchor.surface_text: The petition was referred for trial by the Election Commission to the Election Tribunal, Ratlam, under s. 86 of the Representation of the People Act.

facts.text: Mohan Singh denied publishing the leaflets, submitted they contained factual fair criticism of Bhanwarlal's public activities, not calculated to prejudice.

anchor.surface_text: Mohan Singh by his written statement denied that he had published the leaflets and submitted that the leaflets which appeared to have been published by the electorate contained a factual and fair criticism of the public activities of Bhanwarlal and that they were not calculated to prejudice his prospects at the election.

facts.text: Mohan Singh applied to Tribunal to dismiss petition in limine for non-compliance with s.82, non-joinder of Himmat Singh against whom corrupt practice alleged re withdrawal.

anchor.surface_text: Mohan Singh applied to the Tribunal for an order dismissing the petition in limine on the ground, among others, that there was non-compliance with s. 82 of the Act, because one of the candidates at the election named Himmat Singh--against whom allegations of corrupt practice in regard to the withdrawal of his candidature were made--was not joined as a respondent.

facts.text: Tribunal rejected dismissal application, held Mohan Singh and agents committed corrupt practice u/s123(4) by publishing leaflets D E containing false statements to knowledge/belief false, prejudicial.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal rejected the application for dismissal of the petition and held that it was established on the evidence that Mohan Singh and his agents did commit, amongst others, the corrupt practice defined in s. 123(4) of the Act by publishing the leaflets, annexures D E, containing statements which were false, to the knowledge and belief of Mohan Singh, and made with the knowledge that they would reasonably prejudice the election chances of Bhanwarlal.

facts.text: Tribunal relied primarily on testimony of Rameshchandra, compositor in Maheshwari Printing Press Mandsaur, and corroborative circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: In coming to that conclusion the Tribunal primarily relied upon the testimony of one Rameshchandra, a compositor in the Maheshwari Printing Press, Mandsaur, and upon certain corroborative circumstances.

facts.text: High Court in appeal agreed with Tribunal that Mohan Singh instrumental in getting printed leaflets D E, distributed in villages by Mohan Singh and agents Satyanarayan and Kailash.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal by Mohan Singh against the order, the High Court of Madhya Pradesh on a review of the evidence agreed with the Tribunal that Mohan Singh was instrumental in getting printed leaflets annexures D E and the leaflets were distributed in certain villages in the constituency by Mohan Singh and his agents Satyanarayan and Kailash.

facts.text: On January 20, 1962, Mohan Singh offered at Nahargarh to Himmat Singh help in procuring job in Dalauda Sugar Factory or elsewhere to withdraw candidature.

anchor.surface_text: In paragraph 11 b of the petition it was averred that on January 20, 1962, Mohan Singh, offered at Nahargarh to Shri Himmat Singh an independent candidate to help him in procuring a job for him in Dalauda Sugar Factory or elsewhere to withdraw his candidature from the election.

facts.text: Supreme Court held para 11b does not allege corrupt practice against Himmat Singh, mere offer of help not gratification u/s123(1)B, no need to join Himmat as respondent.

anchor.surface_text: But in our judgment in para 11 b there is no allegation of corrupt practice against Himmat Singh. ... a mere offer to help in securing employment without more is not offer of gratification within the meaning of s. 123(1)(B) of the Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court upheld concurrent findings of Tribunal and High Court that Mohan Singh published and distributed leaflets D E.

anchor.surface_text: The findings recorded by the Tribunal and the High Court are therefore concurrent findings of fact founded on appreciation of oral evidence and no ground is made out for departing from the settled practice of the Court against interference with those concurrent findings of fact.

facts.text: Leaflet annexure D stated Bhanwarlal collected 28 thousand rupees from agriculturists in name of opium licenses, agriculturists did not get licenses or spent much.

anchor.surface_text: Paragraph 3 of annexure D ... We have heard that your friend has collected 28 thousand rupees from several villages in the name of opium. The agriculturists did not get the licenses and those agriculturists who got them had to spend a lot of money and time

facts.text: Leaflet annexure E asked if Bhanwarlal defrauded agriculturists re opium licenses.

anchor.surface_text: Annexure E ... Did you not defraud the agriculturists with respect to the licences of opium ?

facts.text: Bhanwarlal denied collecting funds for himself, stated amounts collected by District Congress Committee, receipts given, went to committee.

anchor.surface_text: Bhanwarlal denied that he had utilised any fund collected from the agriculturists for his own purposes. He stated that some amounts of money were collected from cultivators of opium by the District Congress Committee, and receipts were given by the District Congress Committee

facts.text: No attempt to prove truth of imputations in leaflets by Mohan Singh.

anchor.surface_text: No attempt was made at the trial to prove the truth of the imputations. Even in the written statement filed by Mohan Singh it was not his plea that the imputations against Bhanwarlal were true or that he believed them to be true.

facts.text: Leaflets published shortly before polling as part of political campaign to injure Bhanwarlal's prospects.

anchor.surface_text: From the manner in which and the time when the leaflets annexures D and E were published, there can be no doubt that those leaflets were published as a part of a political campaign to injure the prospects of Bhanwarlal at the election

facts.text: Supreme Court held publication of leaflets constitutes corrupt practice u/s 123(4) RPA 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the corrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123(4) was established.

facts.text: In Sitamau constituency, licences for cultivation of opium granted to agriculturists.

anchor.surface_text: It is common ground that in the territory which forms the Sitamau constituency, licences for cultivation of opium are granted by the authorities to agriculturists

anchor.surface_text: By s. 80 election is liable to be called in question except by an election petition presented in accordance with the provisions of Part VI of the Act. Section 81 prescribes the grounds on which, the persons by whom and the period during which an election petition may be presented,
If the provisions, among others, of ss. 81 or 82 have not been complied with, the Election Commissioner must dismiss the petition  s. 85 ,
and if the Commission does not so order the Tribunal is enjoined by s. 90 3  to dismiss the petition which does not comply with the provisions of ss. 81 or 82.

The Explanation states For the purposes of this clause the term gratification is not restricted to pecuniary gratifications or gratifications estimable in money and it includes all forms of entertainment and all forms of employment for reward but it does not include the payment of any expenses bonafide incurred at, or for the purpose of, any election and duly entered in the account of election expenses referred to in section 78.

The Explanation to sub-s.  1  of s. 123 furnishes an indication as to what in the view of the Parliament amounts to gratification. The Explanation states For the purposes of this clause the term gratification is not restricted to pecuniary gratifications or gratifications estimable in money and it includes all forms of entertainment and all forms of employment for reward but it does not include the payment of any expenses bonafide incurred at, or for the purpose of, any election and duly entered in the account of election expenses referred to in section 78.

concepts.interpretation: Gratification includes non-pecuniary benefits like employment for reward, but not mere offer to help secure employment

On the merits it was urged that Mohan Singh did number publish the leaflets annexures D E and that in any event the publication did number companystitute a companyrupt practice within the meaning of s. 123  4  of the Act. Whether for alleged number-compliance with the requirements of s. ,82 of the Act, the petition by Bhanwarlal was number maintainable must first be determined,

issues.text: Whether the publication of the leaflets amounts to commission of a corrupt practice within the terms of s. 123(4) of the Representation of the People Act, 1951

anchor.surface_text: The next question to be considered is whether the publication of the leaflets amounts to commission of a corrupt practice within the terms of s. 123  4  of the Representation of the People Act, 1951. Section 123 sets out what the diverse companyrupt practices recognised by the Act are. Clause  4  defines a companyrupt practice by publication of false statements calculated to prejudice the prospects of a candidates election.

holdings.text: The election petition was not liable to be dismissed in limine for non-compliance with s.82 due to non-joinder of Himmat Singh as no corrupt practice was alleged against him and mere offer of help to secure employment does not constitute offer of gratification under s.123(1)(B).

anchor.surface_text: But in our judgment in para 11 b there is no allegation of corrupt practice against Himmat Singh.What is alleged is that Mohan Singh had offered to help Himmat Singh in procuring a job in Dalauda Sugar Factory or elsewhere and that as a consequence of that offer Himmat Singh had withdrawn his candidature from the election. There is no express averment in the petition about the acceptance of the offer by Himmat Singh, but it would border upon supererogation to insist that even if offer to help to procure a job amounted to offer of gratification, an allegation that in consequence of this offer Himmat Singh had withdrawn his candidature from the election did not amount to a plea of acceptance of that offer unless it was so expressly averred. However in our view a mere offer of help to secure employment without more is not offer of gratification within the meaning of s. 123(1)(B) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Para 11(b) alleges offer by Mohan Singh but no acceptance or corrupt practice by Himmat; gratification requires valuable thing per explanation to s.123(1), mere help/promise insufficient; thus s.82(b) joinder not required.

holdings.text: In election petitions, corrupt practices must be established beyond reasonable doubt, not mere preponderance of probability.

anchor.surface_text: Counsel for Mohan Singh challenged the finding of the High Court that Mohan Singh was instrumental in publishing the leaflets annexures D E. He urged that in the trial of an election petition approach to the evidence must be as in a criminal trial and no fact may be held proved unless it is established beyond reasonable doubt. The onus of establishing a corrupt practice is undoubtedly on the person who sets it up, and the onus is not discharged on proof of mere preponderance of probability, as in the trial of a civil suit the corrupt practice must be established beyond reasonable doubt by evidence which is clear and unambiguous.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Standard akin to criminal trial due to serious consequences; onus on charger discharged here by clear, corroborated evidence.

holdings.text: Mohan Singh published leaflets annexures D and E through his agents, as held by concurrent findings of Tribunal and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The findings recorded by the Tribunal and the High Court are therefore concurrent findings of fact founded on appreciation of oral evidence and no ground is made out for departing from the settled practice of the Court against interference with those concurrent findings of fact.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concurrent factual findings on oral evidence (Rameshchandra's corroborated testimony, distribution evidence) accepted; no compelling ground to interfere per settled practice; proved beyond reasonable doubt.

holdings.text: Statements in leaflets D and E are false statements of fact relating to personal character or conduct of Bhanwarlal, imputing defrauding and misappropriation of agriculturists' funds for opium licences.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Leaflets allege collection of Rs.28,000 by Bhanwarlal for opium licences which agriculturists didn't get or spent much; innuendo of fraud/misappropriation; Bhanwarlal denied personal collection/utilisation (District Congress Committee); no proof of truth by Mohan Singh.

holdings.text: Publication of leaflets constitutes corrupt practice under s.123(4) as statements false, relating to personal conduct, not believed true by publisher, reasonably calculated to prejudice prospects.
holdings.reasoning_summary: All elements satisfied: publication proved; false per evidence; personal conduct (fraud innuendo); knowledge of falsity (no truth plea/proof, timing/manner shows political campaign to injure); prejudice from content/context (local opium licences knowledge).

holdings.text: 'Statement of fact' under s.123(4) includes innuendo reasonably raised from language and manner of publication.

anchor.surface_text: The expression statement of fact in s. 123(4) includes not only an express imputation but also an innuendo if one such may reasonably be raised from the language in which it is couched and the manner of its publication.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary to interpret leaflets' interrogative/caption forms as imputations of fraud when read together.

holdings.text: Gratification under s.123(1)(B) and Explanation requires something valuable, not mere offer/promise to help secure employment.

anchor.surface_text: However in our view a mere offer of help to secure employment without more is not offer of gratification within the meaning of s. 123(1)(B) of the Act. The expression gratification is not defined in the Act but the Explanation to sub-s. (1) of s. 123 furnishes an indication as to what in the view of the Parliament amounts to gratification.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Explanation includes employment for reward but mere assistance/promise lacks value element; ordinary meaning 'satisfaction' via valuable thing.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court was therefore right in holding that the companyrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123  4  was established.

outcome.relief_summary: Corrupt practice under s.123(4) held established against appellant Mohan Singh; High Court judgment upheld

anchor.surface_text: But in our judgment in para 11 b there is no allegation of corrupt practice against Himmat Singh.What is alleged is that Mohan Singh had offered to help Himmat Singh in procuring a job in Dalauda Sugar Factory or elsewhere and that as a consequence of that offer Himmat Singh had withdrawn his candidature from the election. There is no express averment in the petition about the acceptance of the offer by Himmat Singh, but it would border upon supererogation to insist that even if offer to help to procure a job amounted to offer of gratification, an allegation that in consequence of this offer Himmat Singh had withdrawn his candidature from the election did not amount to a plea of acceptance of that offer unless it was so expressly averred. However in our view a mere offer of help to secure employment without more is not offer of gratification within the meaning of s. 123(1)(B) of the Act.
The High Court was therefore right in holding that the companyrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123  4  was established.
The High Court was therefore right in holding that the companyrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123  4  was established.

anchor.surface_text: The findings recorded by the Tribunal and the High Court are therefore concurrent findings of fact founded on appreciation of oral evidence and no ground is made out for departing from the settled practice of the Court against interference with those concurrent findings of fact.
The High Court was therefore right in holding that the companyrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123  4  was established.

The expression statement of fact in s. 123(4) includes not only an express imputation but also an innuendo if one such may reasonably be raised from the language in which it is couched and the manner of its publication.
The High Court was therefore right in holding that the companyrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123  4  was established.

anchor.surface_text: However in our view a mere offer of help to secure employment without more is not offer of gratification within the meaning of s. 123(1)(B) of the Act. The expression gratification is not defined in the Act but the Explanation to sub-s. (1) of s. 123 furnishes an indication as to what in the view of the Parliament amounts to gratification.
The High Court was therefore right in holding that the companyrupt practice charged against the appellant Mohan Singh under s. 123  4  was established.
